content.description: There are very few placements on this route, and none of them seem very good. It could be led if one feels it'd be worth it. I felt like leaving it as a TR or potential free solo.
content.location:
This is climber's right of

Escape from Hell (1980)

. It shares the same tree anchor.

climbs.name: Naamah
climbs.fa: Mike Robinson, Stu Salinas, Rudy VanVorhees

content.description: Most of this slab route is 5.EZ with a couple of 5.8ish friction moves.... It is a good intro to slab climbing.
content.location: This is the leftmost slab. Follow the "yellow line" to a large tree (pictured).

climbs.name: Mantus
climbs.fa: Stu Salinas, Mike Robinson, Rudy Van Vorhees

content.description: This route wanders up the left side of the rightmost slab. Climb this wandering route on run out slab moves to the top...take the path of least resistance.
content.location: On the rightmost slab (separated by steep slides), climb a couple of delicate slab moves at the start then more straightforward slab moves up to a steep headwall. Finally, traverse climber's right on a bulge, then cut left and up to the top band of trees.

content.description: Start on a finger lieback protecting with 0.5s. Use a combination of smears and thumb stacks up (or lieback) and left under a small roof (bomber #2), then move up into harder moves on smaller gear. The crack thins out to 0.1 or 0.2 (C1/aid at this point) before opening up again and allowing you to cut right and pull the lip into easier climbing. This one is harder than it looks and will take some work (for me anyways) to free (Fritz and I feel it may go free in the 5.12 range).
content.location: This is on the final wall that tops out on the canyon rim. Follow the 3rd class route, Devil's Delight, to the top of the Sedit Slabs. This line will be right in your face as you get up.
